sections.title: Positional Principles
sections.content:
**Pawn Structure**: The foundation of chess strategy. Weak pawns (isolated, doubled, backward) are targets. Strong pawn structures (connected, passed pawns) are assets.

**Piece Activity**: Active pieces are more valuable than passive ones. Centralized pieces control more squares. Rooks belong on open files.

**King Safety**: The king must be protected. Castling is usually essential. Weak king positions invite attacks.

**Space Advantage**: Controlling more squares gives you more options. Space advantage often leads to piece activity.

**Material vs. Position**: Sometimes a positional advantage is worth sacrificing material. A strong attack can be worth a pawn or even a piece.

sections.title: Common Tactical Patterns
sections.content:
**Pin**: A piece cannot move because it would expose a more valuable piece. Absolute pin (against king) vs. relative pin (against other piece).

**Fork**: One piece attacks two or more pieces simultaneously. Knights are masters of the fork.

**Skewer**: Like a pin, but the more valuable piece is in front. When it moves, the piece behind is captured.

**Discovered Attack**: Moving one piece reveals an attack from a piece behind it. Can be devastating!

**Double Attack**: Attacking two targets at once with different pieces.

**Removing the Defender**: Capture or drive away a piece that defends another piece.

**Overloading**: A piece is asked to defend too many things at once.

**Deflection**: Forcing a piece to leave an important square.

**Zwischenzug (In-Between Move)**: A surprising move inserted in a sequence, often a check or capture.

sections.title: Essential Endgame Techniques
sections.content:
**King Activity**: In the endgame, the king becomes a powerful piece. Centralize your king!

**Opposition**: When kings face each other with one square between, the player who doesn't move has the opposition. Crucial in king and pawn endgames.

**Pawn Promotion**: Getting a pawn to the 8th rank wins games. Create passed pawns and support them.

**Lucena Position**: A winning technique for rook and pawn vs. rook endgames.

**Philidor Position**: A drawing technique for rook and pawn vs. rook endgames.

**Triangulation**: A technique to lose a tempo and force zugzwang.

**Zugzwang**: When any move makes your position worse. Common in endgames.

sections.title: Opening Principles (Revisited)
sections.content:
**Control the Center**: e4, d4, e5, d5 are the most important squares. Control them with pawns and pieces.

**Develop Pieces**: Get knights and bishops out early. Don't move the same piece twice unless necessary.

**Castle Early**: Move your king to safety. Usually castle by move 10.

**Don't Bring Queen Out Too Early**: The queen is powerful but vulnerable. Develop minor pieces first.

**Connect Your Rooks**: Clear the back rank so rooks can work together.

**Don't Make Unnecessary Pawn Moves**: Every pawn move creates a weakness. Only move pawns when necessary.

**Don't Waste Time**: Every move should develop a piece, control center, or improve your position.

sections.title: Middlegame Planning
sections.content:
**Attack on the King**: When you have more pieces near the enemy king, attack! Look for weaknesses (exposed king, weak pawns, no defenders).

**Minority Attack**: Attack with fewer pawns to create weaknesses in opponent's majority.

**Pawn Storm**: Advance pawns to attack the enemy king. Common in opposite-side castling positions.

**Piece Maneuvers**: Sometimes you need to reposition pieces. Find the best squares for each piece.

**Prophylaxis**: Anticipate and prevent opponent's plans. Think about what they want to do and stop it.

**Exchange Pieces**: When ahead in material, simplify. When behind, avoid exchanges and complicate.

**Time vs. Material**: Sometimes you need to sacrifice material for time (initiative, attack).

sections.title: Calculation & Visualization
sections.content:
**Look Ahead**: Calculate variations in your head. Start with forcing moves (checks, captures, threats).

**Candidate Moves**: Don't calculate every move. Identify the 2-3 best candidate moves and calculate those.

**Quiescence**: Calculate until the position is quiet (no more forcing moves). Don't stop in the middle of a combination.

**Blunder Check**: Before moving, check: Am I hanging anything? Can my opponent checkmate me? What's their best response?

**Pattern Recognition**: Experienced players recognize patterns instantly. Study tactics to build your pattern library.

**Visualization**: Practice seeing the board in your mind. This improves with experience.
